labels.name: duplicate

labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Some questions about CoSERV
issues.author: Xynnn007
issues.body:
Hi, I am excited to see this standard work on "How to identify reference value" as a confidential computing developer. I have some questions about this

1. This standard specifies how to calibrate reference values. Do we have plans to standardize the reference value return format or the protocol interaction process being queried? The context is that different hardware architectures currently do not have a unified reference value query API, and the APIs for distributing reference values ​​in the software ecosystem are also different. If we standardized this process, it would benefit the confidential computing ecosystem.

2. In the Query Structure of the reference value query, is it necessary to add the "time" optional parameter, which means the reference value that meets other conditions as of a certain time.

Thanks!

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body:
Hi @Xynnn007 and thanks for your interest in this work.

We're quite early in the evolution of this draft, and we don't have a version published to the data tracker yet. At the moment, I think there are some inconsistencies between the text and the CDDL, which I will rectify soon.

For your question [1], the intention of this draft is deliberately only scoped to the query language, not the output format. The idea is that a CoSERV query would form the input to an endorsement distribution service, and there would be a media type negotiation to decide on the best-applicable output format for the consumer. There are different output formats in the ecosystem, and this draft is not intended to compete with or replace those. CoRIM, for example, already has a lot of traction in the RATS world, and indeed CoSERV is heavily influenced by the environment maps used by CoRIM. So you could imagine a service where CoSERV is the input, and CoRIM is the output. But there could also be other output types.

For question [2], this isn't something I had considered. What would be the expected use case for this? It's certainly expected that RV sets might change over time (due to such things as firmware image upgrade, for instance). But I would expect that latest/current values are the most useful thing to a consumer at any given point.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> For question [2], this isn't something I had considered. What would be the expected use case for this? It's certainly expected that RV sets might change over time (due to such things as firmware image upgrade, for instance). But I would expect that latest/current values are the most useful thing to a consumer at any given point.

Quick note: in #20 we added an “expiration date” field to the result set.  The idea is that the endorsement distributor sets this field based on some local knowledge (e.g., configuration, CoRIM's notAfter, signing certificate’s notAfter, etc.).
In the context of a full-blown API, this needs to be syncrhonised with any cache-control signals (e.g., HTTP and CoAP).

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body:
> For your question [1], the intention of this draft is deliberately only scoped to the query language, not the output format.

Just quoting my own comment above. But I need to update on this, because it's no longer true. This was the original intention, but we pivoted on this when we realised that queries and result sets needed to be crypto-bound together in some cases. In the end, we decided to fully define the output format as well, essentially by using a thin wrapper around CoRIM's data model. This means that the design is now somewhat more constrained. But this should have the effect of making CoSERV more useful as a standard, because there will be less inherent variability in what the consumers receive in response to a query. There is still space in the design for carrying non-CoRIM artifacts as CMWs with media type labels.

See also issue [#51](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/issues/51), which will enhance the CoSERV draft to define standard API interaction patterns as well, such as how to transact CoSERV queries over HTTP. This will allow all CoSERV-enabled distributor endpoints to behave according to a common spec, so that a single client library could be developed to talk to all of them.

comments.author: Xynnn007
comments.body:
Another observation is that the reference value providers can include the hardware vendors, but also software delivers (a simple case is a github action which will build the artefact running inside TEE and to be measured)

The latter case is somehow easier to implement.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Our aim is for CoSERV to be applicable across the entire supply chain: hardware, firmware, software. We also support aggregation models, whereby an intelligent service could construct a whole body of endorsement/RV artifacts by combining pieces from different contributing parts of the supply chain, creating a readily-packaged bundle that could be used to appraise an entire system.

issues.title: CoRIM is a normative reference
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
CoRIM is currently stashed in the “informational" bucket.
It should be moved up the ladder.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Fixed by https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/13

issues.title: Security considerations related with the use of CoSERV in the distribution API
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
When using CoSERV with the distribution API, there must be a strong cryptographic binding between the computed result set and the query that triggers it.

Otherwise, an intermediary could play cut & splice with different resources and URIs, potentially compromising the security of the appraisal.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Closed with https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/13

issues.title: query semantics
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We need to clearly explain CoSERV's query semantics, i.e.:

* The entries in the class/istance/group array represent alternatives (`OR`)
* In a given class:
    * All fields that are set must match (`AND`)
    * Any unset fields are wildcards (`*`)

To illustrate the concepts, we can use the `ToSQL` examples in [`coserv/environmentselector_test.go`](https://github.com/veraison/corim/blob/coserv/coserv/environmentselector_test.go)

comments.author: deeglaze
comments.body: I think that a new query language and associated semantics is uncalled for unless it's a CBOR expression of Meta's GraphQL which is /then/ specialized down to selecting CoRIMs or individual tags like the evident single supported tags that have environment-map as a primary key (i.e., CoMID and CoTS).

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Blend this into the prose for information model on queries.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Completed as of [#39](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/39)

issues.title: fix cardinality of the selectors
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We currently have 0..n:
```
selector //= ( &(class: 0) => [ * class-map ] )
```

It should be 1..n:
```
selector //= ( &(class: 0) => [ + class-map ] )
```

issues.title: Result type is more extensible than the query
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
The coserv query can select for `artifact-type` as being either Trust Anchor, Endorsed Value or Reference Value. This is a rigid definition that was chosen to reflect the "RATS-native" artifacts.

However, we also want to support profile-defined extensions, and the result set is defined in such a way to support this via an extension socket in the CDDL.

So there's asymmetry between how extensible the query is, relative to how extensible the result is.

Need to find a good data model idiom to resolve this.

One option might be to simply add a fourth option to `artifact-type` that essentially means "profile-specific" and assume that the profile will handle its semantics.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Update after chatting with @thomas-fossati - we should probably not rush to create extensibility mechanisms until such time as they can be matched to a clear use case, and in particular we should be wary of allowing profiles to introduce wholesale bespoke semantics, because that can end up leading to precisely the kind of fragmentation that we want to address with CoSERV. We should keep this issue open to track the ongoing extensibility problem in the meantime.

issues.title: `application/coserv+cbor` should expose the profile as an optional parameter
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: Similar to [EAT](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-eat-media-type-12.html) and [CoRIM](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-corim-07.html#section-12.12.1) media types.

issues.title: Add a CoAP Content-Format
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: We need to add a request to IANA for a new CoAP Content-Format for the `application/coserv+cbor` media type.

issues.title: Select by signer as well
issues.author: deeglaze
issues.body:
A reference value provider (e.g., Firmware vendor) can provide measurements for an environment whose name it does not own (e.g., Silicon vendor-named bootloader target). If I want to get reference values for the bootloader target that are specifically from a particular signer, then CoSERV does not allow me to name that.

If I select by manifest-signer role in the entity map, then since that's optional for directly signed CoRIMs in favor of the mandatory corim-meta  COSE header, then you'd need to search that as well. We don't even have a required structure for the manifest-signer, so I've opened https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-corim/issues/421

issues.title: Consider "audit bundle" payloads in responses
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
In earlier discussions around Endorsement API endpoints, we theorised two trust models:

- The "shallow" trust model, where the endorsement service alone is trusted to aggregate and convey on behalf of the whole supply chain.
- The "deep" trust model, where the client trusts the endorsement service in the first instance, but may also need access to the original resources that were aggregated from primary supply chain entities.

CoSERV as currently written caters quite well for the shallow model, but we need to think about how it could adopt the deep model (even if our PoC activities exclude that model for now).

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Completed as of [#39](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/39)

issues.title: Describe authority delegation in the result set
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body: We have an existing description of the result set data model, which includes the "quad" concept (the per-triple trust authority), but there is no discussion of how this should be used, particularly where there are inductive chains of authorities.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
The limitation of the current syntax is that it only allows delegation chains of depth 1.  If the delegation chain we need to model is deeper than that — e.g., $$A_1 \rightarrow A_2 \rightarrow … \rightarrow A_n$$ —  our current syntax produces an ambiguity: what authority is the quad referring to?  Is it the most upstream supply chain actor ($$A_1$$), or the last ($$A_n$$)?

This situation may be remediated by allowing the explicit delegation chain:

> $$A_1$$ said that $$A_2$$ said that … said that $$A_n$$ said the $$E$$ has refvals $$R$$.

moving from:
```
refval-quad = {
  &(authority: 1) => $crypto-key-type-choice
  &(rv-triple: 2) => reference-triple-record
}
```
to:
```
refval-quad = {
  &(authorities: 1) => [ + $crypto-key-type-choice ]
  &(rv-triple: 2) => reference-triple-record
}
```

where the `authorities` array encodes the ordered delegation chain — lower values correspond to entities located further upstream.

(If we take this approach, it’s probably worth considering renaming `refval-quad` & friends.)

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Dual-assigned to Thomas and Paul - Thomas to act on the CDDL changes, and Paul to do the write-up in the draft.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Completed as of [#39](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/39)

issues.title: Add a query timestamp to the CoSERV query
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
Rationale is that a combination of the serialised query and the timestamp would make an excellent lookup key into a transparency log.

The purpose of a transparency log would be to capture all of the data that resulted in the set of artefacts delivered by the producer. This allows an alternative audit mechanism where the "deep" model is implemented in a log for retrospective discovery, rather than passed directly to the consumer.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Completed as of [#39](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/39)

issues.title: Add a shallow/deep switch into the CoSERV query
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
Add a binary shallow/deep selector into the CoSERV query, so that the client can exercise control over the amount of data that they receive.

In the shallow model, the client receives only the artefacts that the producer deduces from its downstream sources, along with signing authority information for those downstream sources. In the deep model, the client also receives duplicates of the downstream data directly.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Completed as of [#39](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/39)

issues.title: add CMW CDDL
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Currently, in the CDDL, `cmw-record` is just a stub.

We need to add “the real thing.”

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Fixed in #46

issues.title: Support selection by stateful environments
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
Experiments with existing services such as the [AMD Key Distribution Service](https://wiki.ietf.org/group/rats/referencevalues/amd-key-distribution-service) have shown that endorsement resources sometimes need to be selected by more than just an instance/group/class environment look-up. Additional information about the environment state might also be need to be conveyed in the query. In the case of the AMD KDS, this state would include things like the security revision numbers of the TCB components, which are needed to compute the correct attestation public key and hence provide the correct certificate as endorsement.

Stateful environments are already modelled in CoRIM, so it may be possible to enhance the CoSERV query such that a stateful environment can be expressed in the query.

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Addressed in [#44](https://github.com/rats-endorsements-distribution/draft-howard-rats-coserv/pull/44)

issues.title: Using simple grouping in the stateful environment description complicates the implementation
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
While working on the implementation, I realised we could make it a lot simpler if we used arrays to wrap the stateful class/instance/group rather than pure grouping.
That's not backwards compatible with -02, but we didn't make any promises in that sense, so I think it's entirely appropriate to slightly change the wire format.
CDDL-wise, it’s the same, the implementation is much easier though: casing the stateful stuff in an array simplifies encoding and decoding because each logical entry is dealt with in one go rather than doing two passes:
1. Decode the outer array, leaving the array elements undecoded
2. Iterate through the undecoded array elements, check CBOR type (since the measurements are optional, you can't just say that the odd entries are the measurements) and dispatch to the right item decoder

issues.title: Missing semantic mapping for stateful selector including measurements
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: In §4.3.2.1 (Selector Semantics), we probably want to add an example that shows how a complete stateful environment (including measurements) is mapped into the query syntax.

issues.title: Add section on API binding, starting with HTTP
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
CoSERV is payload-only, and is agnostic of transport or API definition. However, if we aspire to create industry standards for endorsement distribution, then we need to prescribe some endpoint behaviours as well, so that services can be built to a common API specification and support standard interactions.

Such API definitions _could_ be written as companion drafts, but this creates a profusion of documents. In the case of CoSERV, most of the semantics are in the payload, and the API is consequently very minimal: just a single method to execute a query and return the result. Companion drafts seem overkill for this purpose. The more pragmatic approach would be to have API behaviours described in a new section of the CoSERV draft itself.

This request is to add:

- A new top-level section called "API Bindings" or similar
- An initial sub-section of the new top-level section, which details the binding to HTTP, using the [PoC implementation in the Veraison project](https://github.com/veraison/services/tree/coserv) as the source of truth
- An appendix containing an [OpenAPI](https://swagger.io/specification/) document for the HTTP API, which can be referenced from the sub-section

Future sub-sections could then be added for CoAP or other bindings.

issues.title: Add example of a “stateful” query
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Since #44, the ability to query using a stateful environment has been a CoSERV feature.

The examples section may benefit from a practical illustration of the concept.

(Noting that this could build on the `rv-class-stateful.diag` test vector introduced in #48.)

issues.title: Query timestamp removal
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Queries have a non-optional RFC3339 timestamp attached.

The rationale is captured in #28.

At the time, we overlooked the fact that this field may adversely affect the caching properties that the coserv payloads require.

Long story short: we should remove the field and add something SCITT-y, instead.

issues.title: Populate Discovery section
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body:
Body text, CDDL model and examples for the Discovery sub-section.
CDDL needs to support both JSON and CBOR
Media types need to be added for both

issues.title: Body text for all API sections
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body: Write all of the normative body text for the API chapter.

issues.title: Example HTTP request/response transactions
issues.author: paulhowardarm
issues.body: Add HTTP example requests and responses for each of the documented HTTP status codes, plus some examples of caching.

issues.title: Add HTTP example requests and responses for each of the documented HTTP status codes
issues.author: thomas-fossati

issues.title: Add HTTP example requests and responses with caching headers
issues.author: thomas-fossati

issues.title: CoSERV lacks mechanism for Target Environment completeness verification
issues.author: fdamato
issues.body:
**Description**: 
CoSERV enables querying Reference Values for individual Target Environments but provides no mechanism for a Verifier to determine the complete set of Target Environments that an Attester should report in Evidence. This creates a security vulnerability where compromised Attesters can omit measurements from Target Environments in poor state.
**Problem Statement:**

- Per RFC 9334, an Attester contains multiple Target Environments
- A compromised Attester could selectively omit Target Environment claims
- Verifiers need authoritative information about expected Target Environment inventory
- CoSERV queries are environment-specific but don't address environment set completeness

**Proposed Solution:**
Add a new CoSERV query type for "Expected Target Environment Inventory" that returns the complete set of Target Environments that should be measured by a given Attester class/instance.
**Implementation Considerations:**

- Requires Attester identification scheme (proposed: vendor/model tuple)
- The minimum set of Target Environments that must be verified should be derived from the collection of all Target Environments present across all available CoRIMs for that Attester

**Open Design Question:** Should this be a **new CoSERV query type** or an **extension to existing environment queries**?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Hi @fdamato, thanks for bringing this up!

As briefly discussed in the related email thread, CoRIM shares the same problem, which we are trying to address using [Domain Membership Triples](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-corim-08.html#name-domain-membership-triple) (DMT).

Currently, CoSERV does not support DMTs, but this could easily be added if needed.  Note that the DMT subject (`domain-type`) is an `environment-map` and is therefore perfectly aligned with CoSERV’s query machinery.

issues.title: Carl’s (partial) review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
@carl-wallace’s (partial) review: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/ouEOxv4b8myEc88tIPNDq17P4rs/


- How one would implement "shallow trust" and "deep trust" is not clear to me. I think this stems from the fact that Endorsements are secure statements and Reference Values are not. Should "shallow trust" be limited to conveying Reference Values?
 
- "Shallow trust" suggests a need to include Attestation Results in the result set (which in turn suggests including Evidence and Appraisal Policy in the query). CoServ seems a bit like SCVP with "deep trust" being analogous to "delegated path building" but "shallow trust" stopping short of "delegated path validation."
 
- How are verifiers (or aggregators) supposed to locate aggregators or supply chain actors?
 
- Can/should CoSERV be used between aggregator and supply chain actors? If so, make this clearer in Section 2 (for example in the statement "would have the ability to contact all contributing supply chain actors" and in the last paragraph).
 
- I think the term "Endorser" is used too loosely throughout. For example, Section 2 says: “In pure RATS terms, an aggregator is still an Endorser or a Reference Value Provider - or, more likely, both.” Is an aggregator an "Endorser" or an "Endorsement Provider"? Given an endorsement is a "secure statement", referring to an aggregator as an "Endorser" does not seem right.
 
- In 3.1, given the concerns about caching, why is a nonce not used?
 
- In 4.3.3, it may be worth clarifying whether the timestamp informs how a result-set is prepared, i.e., whether result-sets should be relative to the point in time indicated by the timestamp or result-sets are always relative to the current time of the result-set provider.
 
- In 4.4, should results also have a timestamp value indicating when result set was prepared?
 
- In 3.2, do we expect trust anchor keys to be used to sign evidence? A better example may be a public key used to verify a certification oath to a certificate containing a public key used to verify evidence. This begs the questions is one bucket of trust anchors sufficient, i.e., ought they be differentiated by purpose, and are there any intermediate public keys that should also be conveyed, i.e., intermediate certificates?
 
- The EAT I-D reference should be updated to RFC 9711.
 
- 4.3.2.1 states "the implementation of the artifact producer MUST consider these to be alternatives." Is "producer" the right term here if the recipient of the query is an aggregator? This section may benefit from a courtesy reproduction of the class-map type (or at least a reference to it).
 
- Should artifact-type have an artifact-type-extensions to align with result-set? If not, what would prompt adding a new result-set type?
 
- In 4.3.4, suggest replacing "either" with "the desired type(s) of results: ".
 
- This sentence in the Security Considerations is confusing: "It does not directly convey Evidence, Endorsements, Reference Values, Policies or Attestation Results." Should Endorsements and Reference Values be removed, the entire sentence deleted, or is there some meaning of "directly" that makes the sentence accurate? How does this relate to "shallow trust"? Similarly, the statement “there are fewer security considerations for CoSERV” would seem to vary with shallow or deep trust.
 
- The Security Considerations section should address conveyance of trust anchors, which have very different security considerations than conveying secure statements like Endorsements.

pulls.title: Restructure the draft to latest CDDL
pulls.author: paulhowardarm
pulls.body:
A round of extensions and refactoring to match the draft prose to the CDDL data model.

- Introduction is rewritten to expand the scope of CoSERV to include both queries _and_ result sets.
- A new top-level "Information Model" section is introduced, so that we can keep informational concepts and structure distinct from the precise data model.
- Top-level "CoSERV Query Language" heading changed to "Data Model"
- CDDL section refactored to reflect the new top-level wrapper object, with the query now nested within it.

This is just a minimal set to make the prose more honest with respect to the CDDL. After this, we can probably do more refactoring to lift some verbosity out of the data model and put it into the information model instead.

Signed-off-by: Paul Howard <paul.howard@arm.com>

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Looks great!  I have inlined a couple suggestions.

comments.body: Non-native speaker question: is “mitigate against something” or “mitigate something”?  (In Italian, “mitigate” does not require any proposition because it is a transitive verb.)

Maybe we can be more specific.  (The `?` in the ref implicitly makes an “informational reference” entry.  However, we probably want to be consistent with the current model — i.e., being explicit.)

```suggestion
An example of this is caching in HTTP {{?STD98}} and CoAP {{?RFC7252}}.
```
Countering manipulation by an untrusted intermediary also needs a cryptographic envelope around the CoSERV data item.
Good catch. Slapdash usage on my part. Will correct.
Nice — we’ll need to request registration of the CoAP Content-Format (added #15 to track this.)

comments.body:
slightly more concise

```suggestion
The profile and query structures are the same as in the previous examples.
```

new-sentence-new-line (as per convention)
```suggestion
The result structure is a map with two entries: `expiry` (codepoint 10) and `reference-value triples` (codepoint 0).
A single reference-value triple is shown in this example. Its `environment-map`, as expected, is the same as the `environment-map` that was supplied in the query.
The rest of the structure is the `measurement-map` as defined in CoRIM {{-rats-corim}}.
```

pulls.title: Add authority to the result triples
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
First stab at adding explicit authority to result triples.

The idea explored in this PR is to wrap the existing triples in a map, which contains the authority context as "crypto-key.”

The downside of this approach is that it could potentially become extremely redundant, especially if the crypto-key is a cert or a cert chain.

Possible mitigations include using "CBOR packed” or creating an auxiliary dictionary.

pulls.title: feat(cddl): shallow/deep switch
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
Add a shallow/deep switch into the CoSERV query and a corresponding
entry in the result set to stash the source RIMs.

Partially addresses #29

comments.body: Can we call this `include-audit` rather than `include-rims`. Or at least choose a slightly more agnostic term than `rims`, because I'm worried that it might be implying more about the structure of the audit data than we can reasonably know. "Audit" might not be the best term, either, because that somewhat implies a whole process rather than just raw data. Maybe `include-audit-material` or `include-source-material` or something similarly evocative?

Again, `rims` feels too knowledgeable about the data. Perhaps if we call this field `source-material` in the result set, then the switch can be `include-source-material` and we have aligned the names.

On a related note, do we need to label these source blobs with any media type information?

> Again, `rims` feels too knowledgeable about the data. Perhaps if we call this field `source-material` in the result set, then the switch can be `include-source-material` and we have aligned the names.

Sounds like a good improvement.

> On a related note, do we need to label these source blobs with any media type information?

Also this one.  It seems like a good use of CMWs.
OK.  I’d go with `include-source-material`.

pulls.title: Flesh out the result set description
pulls.author: paulhowardarm
pulls.body:
Add a more comprehensive description of the result set, inclusive of the recent CDDL changes to allow for audit bundles and multiple authority delegates.

Signed-off-by: Paul Howard <paul.howard@arm.com>

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Awesome, thanks.  I have inlined a couple of editorial suggestion for your consideration.  (Since I am a bit less English than you are, feel free to chuck them in the bin!)

comments.body:
I have been told a few times that the active form is preferable.  (Feel free to ditch this suggestion.)

```suggestion
The result set contains the artifacts that the producer collected in response to the query.
```

Rather than “or extensions”, I would put a full stop right after “trust anchors” and add a separate sentence that says something like “In the future, the result entry types can be extended” (or simialr)

suggest removing some redundancy

```suggestion
The artifacts in the result collection therefore MUST match the single artifact type specified in the original CoSERV query.
```

pulls.title: Document-wide refactoring and improvements
pulls.author: paulhowardarm
pulls.body:
- Catch up the draft text to the latest data model
- Assorted prose refactoring - move some verbosity out of the data model so that it's just CDDL and light descriptions
- Describe aggregation and trust models
- Define environment selector semantics

Signed-off-by: Paul Howard <paul.howard@arm.com>

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Looks great.  I have inlined a few comments.

comments.body: While the sentence is factually correct, I sense that using “Attester” and “composite” in the same sentence is going to create the wrong association in the RATS reader’s mind.  Can we use “complex” instead?

We seem to use "Endorsement and Reference Values” consistently throughout the document.
Using the term “endorsements" here may cause confusion.
I suggest we do one of two things:
1. Replace "endorsements" with "Endorsement and Reference Values", or
2. Introduce lowercase “endorsements" as shorthand for "Endorsement and Reference Values” in the terminology section, and then perform a mass substitution.
s/and caters/catering/ ?

While I’d expect this to be true in the vast majority of cases, there may be pathological situations where it may not hold.  I think it’s safer to remove L134.  Alternatively, we could s/inevitably/typically/ , s/inevitably/quite possible/ or similar weasel words.
Another use case for “source-artifacts” is that of a pure broker, pulling from multiple upstream sources for its downstream aggregators.

Here comes the NSNL police! ;-)

```suggestion
The same applies for class-based selectors.
However, since class selectors are themselves composed of multiple inner fields, the implementation of the artifact producer MUST use a logical `AND` operation in consideration of the inner fields for each class.
```

Alternatively:

```suggestion
The same applies for class-based selectors; however, since class selectors are themselves composed of multiple inner fields, the implementation of the artifact producer MUST use a logical `AND` operation in consideration of the inner fields for each class.
```
In this case, {{Section 3.4.1 of -cbor}} provides a more precise reference than {{RFC3339}}.

```suggestion
In CoRIM {{-rats-corim}}, stateful environments are modeled as an environment identifier plus a collection of measurements, and CoSERV takes the same approach.
```
Just as a data point: another example would be a PSA certification, which comprises both the immutable PRoT and “some” of the mutable PRoT components.
That would be an interesting thing to explore - using CoSERV to query for PSA endorsements.
Sure, let’s keep that in mind.

pulls.title: Body text for API binding sections
pulls.author: paulhowardarm
pulls.body:
Draft prose changes:

- New paragraph in the introduction to indicate the presence of API bindings and reference the relevant section
- Body text for API bindings in general
- Body text for the HTTP request-response binding (currently the only one being specified)
- Body text around the example request/responses

Discovery section and caching section to do later (not this PR).

Signed-off-by: Paul Howard <paul.howard@arm.com>

comments.author: paulhowardarm
comments.body: Courtesy note @shefali-kamal @henkbirkholz - I plan to merge this PR within the next day or two, just in case you have pending review feedback.

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Nice stuff.  I have inlined a few editorial comments.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This is a simple pattern, and likely to be a commonly occurring one for a variety of use cases.
```

```suggestion
The API is a simple protocol for the execution of CoSERV queries.
```

In HTTP/ReST, the term “resource representation” has a [very specific meaning](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#section-3.2).  In this case, rather than “canonical representation of a resource”, I’d say “unique and stable identifier of the [target resource](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#section-7.1)” - or similar.

This is not the usual base64, it’s "base64 encoding using the URL-safe alphabet with padding removed" :-)

I suggest that instead of that, we reuse the term "Base64Url Encoding” defined in the [glossary of JWS](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7515.html#section-2).

Besides, to align with the comment above (i.e., target resource identification) and to be more preceis in terms of how the URI is constructed, I suggest something like:

```suggestion
The Base64Url encoding {{Section 2 of !RFC7515}} of the byte sequence becomes the rightmost path segment of the URI used to identify the target resource.
```

```suggestion
The HTTP `GET` verb is then used with this URI to execute the query.
```
I think that this (L514) is a deployment consideration rather than a protocol one; as such, it doesn’t belong here.

```suggestion
The URL path is formed of the discovered `coserv` endpoint (as set out in {{secrrapidisco}}), followed by a path separator ('/'), followed by the CoSERV query to be executed, which is represented as a Base64Url encoding of the query's serialized CBOR byte sequence.
```
I think that's reasonable. I actually took this text from the SCRAPI draft, but maybe it's no more appropriate there than it is here. Happy to remove this line.
